Besides dynamic type sizing, sfthemes can also scale all other elements of the plot. This is being done by multiplying all element sizes with a specific multiplier. Keep in mind that these values will scale the existing sizes of each elements; therefore, it is recommended that you do not try to scale your entire plot if you are using `size` or `lwd` as one of your `aes`.

| class| multiplier |
|------|-----|
| xSmall | 0.75 |
| Small | 1 |
| Medium | 1.25 |
| Large | 2 |
| xLarge | 3 |
| xxLarge | 4 |
| xxxLarge | 5 |

```R
library(ggplot2); library(sfthemes)

x <- seq(0.01, .99, length.out = 100)
df <- data.frame(
    x = rep(x, 2),
    y = c(qlogis(x), 2 * qlogis(x)),
    group = rep(c("a","b"),
                each = 100)
)

scale = "Medium" # <-- Adjust the scaling factor here!

ggplot(df, aes(x=x, y=y)) +
    geom_line(aes(colour = group), linetype = 2, show.legend = TRUE) +
    labs(title = "xSmall Scale", subtitle = "xSmall subtitle", x = "X", y = "Y", color = "Group") +
    theme_sf_dark(scale = scale) + scale_color_watchos_dark() +
    theme(legend.position = "bottom") 
```
